snippet: Scientists think that abnormal protein deposits inside brain cells cause frontotemporal degeneration.
abstract: University of California, San Francisco, studies of frontotemporal degeneration are leading scientists to believe that the dementia is caused by abnormal protein deposits inside brain cells; proteins vary, but they do not include amyloid, the substance found in Alzheimer's patients. (M)
lead_paragraph: ''If there's something to be done, I want to be in on the ground floor,'' said Elizabeth, 67, a woman participating in studies of frontotemporal degeneration at the University of California, San Francisco. She asked to be identified by only her middle name to protect her privacy. She is healthy, but she has tested positive for a rare gene that makes the brain disease virtually inevitable; her father, her grandmother, two of her three brothers and other relatives have been affected.

headline.main: Studies Tie Abnormal Protein Buildup to Dementia
